properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect snow possibly heavy at times is expected to continue off Georgian Bay. Brief periods of very poor visibility in heavy snow will be likely at times tonight and early Wednesday morning. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are possible. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T17:14:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T06:49:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1485431410.2020
Area: Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible overnight and Wednesday morning. Snow squall activity has diminished. The activity may reintensify overnight and persist into Wednesday morning before dissipating. Local snowfall amounts of up to 15 cm will be possible. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong winter storm will continue to give heavy snow to the Columbias today. A further 10 to 20 cm can be expected today before the snow tapers to flurries late this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-02T03:12:33-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets changing to rain along with strong winds expected tonight. Additional snowfall amounts: up to 2 cm for eastern mainland Nova Scotia, with up to 10 cm for parts of Cape Breton. Additional rainfall amounts: 2 to 10 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h. Locations: Eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: Into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow or rain mixed with ice pellets will continue over eastern parts of the province tonight. There is a risk of freezing rain before the changeover to rain. Strong southeast winds gusting to 70 to possibly 80 km/h will continue tonight before diminishing early Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T13:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T04:36:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3912260759.2020
Area: Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall amounts of 2 cm expected. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: now into early this morning. Remarks: Coastal regions of Miramichi county and the Acadian Peninsula may see a changeover to freezing drizzle or drizzle before tapering off to flurries later in the morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T13:59:09-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong winter storm gave heavy snow to the Kootenays on Tuesday. As the system leaves the region today, further amounts of up to 5 cm can be expected this morning before the snow tapers to flurries. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight. Flurries at times heavy are affecting portions of the Bruce Peninsula. The activity is expected to persist for much of the night into Wednesday morning over the Bruce Peninsula. Snowfall amounts of 15 cm are possible in some areas by late Wednesday morning. Strong westerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will also result in occasional blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T16:17:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T06:47:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0772950077.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible later tonight into Wednesday morning. Lake effect snow off Georgian Bay is expected to intensify and continue into Wednesday morning. Snowfall amounts may approach 15 cm in some areas. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight into Wednesday morning. Lake effect snow off Georgian Bay is expected to continue into Wednesday morning. The lake effect snow bands are expected to shift from time to time which will help limit accumulations at any given location. Local amounts may exceed 15 cm by late Wednesday morning. The lake effect snow will weaken by Wednesday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibilities will in poor in snow and blowing snow today. A coastal low pressure system is moving toward the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Snowfall amounts between 10 and 15 centimetres with easterly winds to 70 km/h are expected over the Lower North Shore. These conditions will give blowing snow for several hours during the day. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-02T00:59:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T09:53:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2172252559.2020
Area: Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog in areas south of Great Slave Lake is expected to dissipate late this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system tracking into the Yukon will bring strong easterly winds and light snow to the Dempster beginning early this morning. The strong winds combined with light falling snow will give blizzard conditions across the entire region beginning this morning and continuing into Thursday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-02T03:55:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T11:56:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1648380836.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

Storm totals near 100 mm are expected. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, is expected. A frontal system over the BC Coast will continue to give heavy rain to inland sections of the Central Coast tonight and Wednesday morning. Rainfall totals near 80 mm are possible by the time rain eases late Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Remarks: Winds will ease and shift to southwesterly this afternoon. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. The snow will be accompanied by locally blowing snow. Conditions will improve Wednesday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of severely cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chills will develop Wednesday night, and will last until Friday. The wind chill is expected to reach -55 in Grise Fiord, but stronger winds and colder temperatures in Resolute Bay will give wind chills closer to -66 Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-02T01:26:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-01T09:27:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2463049308.2020
Area: Resolute, Grise Fiord
properties.Author: Environment Canada
